Articles.Content:
As the first craft shared by NADI (New Age Defense Initiative), we did our best to make it look good, and to make it fly well, an objective we accomplished!

We are proud to present the "Slow And Low" Arrow series of atmospheric planes designed (mainly) for civilian use.

Here is the civilian version of the Arrow, a sleek and narrow design to cut through even the thickest of atmospheres (warranty void if exposed to vacuum).

Outfitted with ASAS and an Avionics pod for maximum control and precise movement. Starting at only 500,000 Kerbucks! (Open to change)

This plane does what it says on the tin, it flies slow, at a cruising speed of ~120m/s and raises very slowly. It can only take off when reaching the end of the runway (warranty void if exposed to water).

Civilian Version .craft http://www./view/2noibwbbf983163/SAL_Arrow_(Civi_Version).craft

TOP SECRET stuff from here down! Shhh!

Here is the military version, a much faster version of the civilian Arrow, it does not do what it says on the tin, it flies fast at a cruising speed of ~200m/s and can raise very rapidly.

The military version comes with two places to equip weapons below the wings. In the provided .craft it comes with unguided radioisotope nuclear bombs. It also has the ability to add fuel drop tanks for longer journeys and can attach missiles to the end of the wings.

Here are some photos in flight (the civilian version flies much like the military version, and can be landed).

Here's the military version sitting on the runway waiting for it's next order to strike.

Here it is seen with it's lights on to allow easy landing at night.

Here, the Arrow dropped it's ordinance into the ocean. Take that Kraken!

And here was my failed attempt at a landing. No worries, the pilot lived (NADI is not responsible for any death caused by our products).

Military Version .craft http://www./view/xhm562itylabv8n/SAL_Arrow_(Military_Version).craft

If anyone asks, these aren't our planes, unless they're on the winning side. If they are on the winning side, then yes, they are our planes (NADI is not responsible for loss of pride, lives, or war because of our products).
